entities.title: Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson
entities.description: Bjørnstjerne Martinius Bjørnson was a Norwegian writer who received the 1903 Nobel Prize in Literature "as a tribute to his noble, magnificent and versatile poetry, which has always been distinguished by both the freshness of its inspiration and the rare purity of its spirit", becoming the first Norwegian Nobel laureate. He was a prolific polemicist and extremely influential in Norwegian public li

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Literature
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Literature is a Swedish literature prize that is awarded annually, since 1901, to an author from any country who has, in the words of the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, "in the field of literature, produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic direction". Though individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is based on an aut

heading: Deaths
txt: John Bunny, American actor (b. 1863)

entities.title: John Bunny
entities.description: John Bunny was an American actor. Bunny began his career as a stage actor, but transitioned to a film career after joining Vitagraph Studios around 1910. At Vitagraph, Bunny made over 150 short films – many of them domestic comedies with the comedian Flora Finch – and became one of the most well-known actors of his era.

heading: Deaths
txt: Srinivasa Ramanujan, Indian mathematician and theorist (b. 1887)

entities.title: Srinivasa Ramanujan
entities.description: Srinivasa Ramanujan was an Indian mathematician who lived during the British Rule in India. Though he had almost no formal training in pure mathematics, he made substantial contributions to mathematical analysis, number theory, infinite series, and continued fractions, including solutions to mathematical problems then considered unsolvable. Ramanujan initially developed his own mathematical resear

heading: Deaths
txt: William Lockwood, English cricketer (b. 1868)

entities.title: Bill Lockwood (cricketer)
entities.description: William Henry Lockwood was an English Test cricketer, best known as a fast bowler and the unpredictable, occasionally devastating counterpart to the amazingly hard-working Tom Richardson for Surrey in the early County Championship. A capable enough batsman against weaker bowling sides who scored over 10,000 runs in first-class cricket, stronger bowling tended to show flaws in his technique.

heading: Deaths
txt: Arturs Alberings, Latvian politician, former Prime Minister of Latvia (b. 1876)

entities.title: Arturs Alberings
entities.description: Arturs Alberings was the 6th Prime Minister of Latvia. He held office from 7 May 1926 to 18 December 1926.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Latvia
entities.description: The prime minister of Latvia is the most powerful member of the Government of Latvia, and presides over the Latvian Cabinet of Ministers. The prime minister is nominated by the president of Latvia, but must be able to obtain the support of a majority of the Saeima (parliament).

heading: Deaths
txt: Carl Bosch, German chemist and engineer, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1874)

entities.title: Carl Bosch
entities.description: Carl Bosch was a German chemist and engineer and Nobel Laureate in Chemistry. He was a pioneer in the field of high-pressure industrial chemistry and founder of IG Farben, at one point the world's largest chemical company.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. heading: Deaths
txt: Violette Morris, French footballer, shot putter, and discus thrower (b. 1893)

entities.title: Violette Morris
entities.description: Violette Morris was a French athlete who won two gold and one silver medal at the Women's World Games in 1921–1922. She was later banned from competing for violating "moral standards." During World War II, she was accused of collaboration with Nazis and the Vichy France regime. She was killed in 1944 in a Resistance-led ambush.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sigmund Rascher, German physician (b. 1909)

entities.title: Sigmund Rascher
entities.description: Sigmund Rascher was a German SS doctor. He conducted deadly experiments on humans pertaining to high altitude, freezing and blood coagulation under the patronage of SS leader Heinrich Himmler, to whom his wife Karoline "Nini" Diehl had direct connections. When police investigations uncovered that the couple had defrauded the public with their supernatural fertility by 'hiring' and kidnapping babie

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Hetman of Ukraine
entities.description: Hetman of Ukraine is a former historic government office and political institution of Ukraine that is equivalent to a head of state.

heading: Deaths
txt: James Larkin White, American miner, explorer, and park ranger (b. 1882)

entities.title: James Larkin White
entities.description: James Larkin White, better known as Jim White, was a cowboy, guano miner, cave explorer, and park ranger for the National Park Service. He is best remembered as the discoverer, early promoter and explorer of what is known today as Carlsbad Caverns in Carlsbad Caverns National Park, New Mexico.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Murray Hulbert, American lawyer, judge, and politician (b. 1881)

entities.title: George Murray Hulbert
entities.description: George Murray Hulbert was a United States Representative from New York and a United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

heading: Deaths
txt: Arnold Sommerfeld, German physicist and academic (b. 1868)

entities.title: Arnold Sommerfeld
entities.description: Arnold Johannes Wilhelm Sommerfeld, was a German theoretical physicist who pioneered developments in atomic and quantum physics, and also educated and mentored many students for the new era of theoretical physics. He served as doctoral supervisor for many Nobel Prize winners in physics and chemistry.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward Arnold, American actor (b. 1890)

entities.title: Edward Arnold (actor)
entities.description: Günther Edward Arnold Schneider was an American actor of the stage and screen.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gichin Funakoshi, Japanese martial artist, founded Shotokan (b. 1868)

entities.title: Gichin Funakoshi
entities.description: Gichin Funakoshi  is the founder of Shotokan karate-do, perhaps the most widely known style of karate, and is known as a "father of modern karate". Following the teachings of Anko Itosu and Anko Asato, he was one of the Okinawan karate masters who introduced karate, but after Ankō Itosu sensei, Funakoshi sensei's teacher, had introduced the art pre-1922, to the Japanese mainland in 1922. He taught

entities.title: Shotokan

heading: Deaths
txt: E. J. Pratt, Canadian poet and author (b. 1882)

entities.title: E. J. Pratt
entities.description: Edwin John Dove Pratt, who published as E. J. Pratt, was "the leading Canadian poet of his time." He was a Canadian poet from Newfoundland who lived most of his life in Toronto, Ontario. A three-time winner of the country's Governor General's Award for poetry, he has been called "the foremost Canadian poet of the first half of the century."

heading: Deaths
txt: John Heartfield, German illustrator and photographer (b. 1891)

entities.title: John Heartfield
entities.description: John Heartfield was a German visual artist who pioneered the use of art as a political weapon. Some of his most famous photomontages were anti-Nazi and anti-fascist statements. Heartfield also created book jackets for book authors, such as Upton Sinclair, as well as stage sets for contemporary playwrights, such as Bertolt Brecht and Erwin Piscator.

heading: Deaths
txt: Morihei Ueshiba, Japanese martial artist, founded aikido (b. 1883)

entities.title: Morihei Ueshiba
entities.description: Morihei Ueshiba  was a Japanese martial artist and founder of the martial art of aikido. He is often referred to as "the founder" Kaiso (開祖) or Ōsensei (大先生/翁先生), "Great Teacher".

entities.title: Aikido

Aikido is now practiced in around 140 countries. It was originally developed by Morihei Ueshiba, as a synthesis of his martial studies, philosophy and religious beliefs. heading: Deaths
txt: Erik Bergman, Swedish minister and author (b. 1886)

entities.title: Erik Bergman (Lutheran minister)
entities.description: Erik Henrik Fredrik Bergman was a Swedish parish minister of the Lutheran Church and the father of diplomat Dag Bergman, novelist Margareta Bergman, and film director Ingmar Bergman.

entities.title: Sidney Franklin (bullfighter)
entities.description: Sidney Franklin was the first American to become a successful matador, the most senior level of bullfighter.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cicely Courtneidge, Australian-born British actress, comedian and singer (b. 1893)

entities.title: Cicely Courtneidge
entities.description: Dame Esmerelda Cicely Courtneidge, was an Australian-born British actress, comedian and singer. The daughter of the producer and playwright Robert Courtneidge, she was appearing in his productions in the West End by the age of 16, and was quickly promoted from minor to major roles in his Edwardian musical comedies.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jim Davis, American actor (b. 1909)

entities.title: Jim Davis (actor)
entities.description: Jim Davis was an American actor, best known for his role as Jock Ewing in the CBS prime-time soap opera, Dallas, a role which continued until he was too ill from a terminal illness to perform.

heading: Deaths
txt: Count Basie, American pianist, composer, and bandleader (b. 1904)

entities.title: Count Basie
entities.description: William James "Count" Basie was an American jazz pianist, organist, bandleader, and composer. In 1935, Basie formed his own jazz orchestra, the Count Basie Orchestra, and in 1936 took them to Chicago for a long engagement and their first recording. heading: Deaths
txt: Broderick Crawford, American actor (b. 1911)

entities.title: Broderick Crawford
entities.description: William Broderick Crawford was an American stage, film, radio, and television actor, often cast in tough-guy roles and best known for his Oscar- and Golden Globe-winning portrayal of Willie Stark in All the King's Men (1949) and for his starring role as Dan Mathews in the television series Highway Patrol (1955–1959).

heading: Deaths
txt: Shankar, Indian composer and conductor (b. 1922)

entities.title: Shankar Jaikishan
entities.description: Shankar Jaikishan, were a popular and successful Indian composer duo of the Hindi film industry, working together from 1949 to 1971. They are considered to be among the greatest and first composer duo of the Hindi film industry. Later, Shankar continued to function as a Music Director alone, still giving music under the banner Shankar-Jaikishan, till 1986.

txt: John Silkin, English lawyer and politician, Shadow Leader of the House of Commons (b. 1923)

entities.title: Shadow Leader of the House of Commons
entities.description: The Shadow Leader of the House of Commons is a member of the Official Opposition Shadow Cabinet responsible for working with the Leader of the House in arranging Commons business and holding the Government to account in its overall management of the House. The Shadow Leader also responds to the Business Statement of Leader of House each Thursday, though the Leader of the Opposition exercised this

heading: Deaths
txt: Lucille Ball, American model, actress, comedian, and producer (b. 1911)

entities.title: Lucille Ball
entities.description: Lucille Désirée Ball was an American actress, comedian, model, studio executive, and producer. As one of Hollywood's greatest icons, and arguably the most iconic female entertainer of all time, she was the star and producer of sitcoms I Love Lucy, The Lucy Show, Here's Lucy, as well as comedy television specials aired under the title The Lucy-Desi Comedy Hour. She was also the first female head of

heading: Deaths
txt: Leo Arnaud, French-American composer and conductor (b. 1904)

entities.title: Leo Arnaud
entities.description: Leo Arnaud or Léo Arnaud was a French American composer of film scores, best known for "Bugler's Dream", which is used as the theme by television networks presenting the Olympic Games in the United States.

txt: Carmine Coppola, American composer and conductor (b. 1910)

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Hatfield, Canadian lawyer and politician, 26th Premier of New Brunswick (b. 1931)

entities.title: Premier of New Brunswick
entities.description: The premier of New Brunswick is the first minister for the Canadian province of New Brunswick. They are the province's head of government and de facto chief executive.

heading: Deaths
txt: Masutatsu Ōyama, Japanese martial artist, founded Kyokushin kaikan (b. 1923)

entities.title: Mas Oyama
entities.description: Masutatsu Ōyama , more commonly known as Mas Oyama, was a karate master who founded Kyokushin Karate, considered the first and most influential style of full contact karate. A Zainichi Korean, he spent most of his life living in Japan and acquired Japanese citizenship in 1968.

entities.title: Kyokushin
entities.description: Kyokushin (極真) is a style of stand-up fighting and was founded in 1964 by Korean-Japanese Masutatsu Oyama . "Kyokushin" is Japanese for "the ultimate truth". It is rooted in a philosophy of self-improvement, discipline and hard training. Its full contact style has international appeal.

heading: Deaths
txt: Stirling Silliphant, American screenwriter and producer (b. 1918)

entities.title: Stirling Silliphant
entities.description: Stirling Dale Silliphant was an American screenwriter and producer. He is best remembered for his screenplay for In the Heat of the Night, for which he won an Academy Award in 1967, and for creating the television series Naked City][Perry Mason and Route 66. Other features as screenwriter include the Irwin Allen productions The Towering Inferno and The Poseidon Adventure.

heading: Deaths
txt: Adrian Borland, English singer-songwriter, guitarist, and producer (b. 1957)

entities.title: Adrian Borland
entities.description: Adrian Kelvin Borland was an English singer, songwriter, guitarist and record producer, best known as the frontman of post-punk band The Sound.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jill Dando, English journalist and television personality (b. 1961)

entities.title: Rosemary Brown (politician)
entities.description: Rosemary Brown was a Canadian politician.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward Max Nicholson, Irish environmentalist, co-founded the World Wide Fund for Nature (b. 1904)

entities.title: World Wide Fund for Nature
entities.description: The World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) is an international non-governmental organization founded in 1961 that works in the field of wilderness preservation and the reduction of human impact on the environment. It was formerly named the World Wildlife Fund, which remains its official name in Canada and the United States.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hubert Selby, Jr., American author, poet, and screenwriter (b. 1928)

entities.title: Hubert Selby, Jr.
entities.description: Hubert "Cubby" Selby Jr. was an American writer. His best-known novels are Last Exit to Brooklyn (1964) and Requiem for a Dream (1978), exploring worlds in the New York area. Both novels were adapted later as films, and he appeared in small roles in each.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mason Adams, American actor (b. 1919)

entities.title: Mason Adams
entities.description: Mason Adams was an American character actor and voice-over artist. From the late 1940s until the early 1970s he was heard in numerous radio programs and voiceovers for television commercials, the latter of which he resumed in the 1980s and 90s. In the early 1970s he moved into acting and from 1977 to 1982 held perhaps his most known role, that of Managing Editor Charlie Hume on Lou Grant. He also

heading: Deaths
txt: Jack Valenti, American businessman, created the MPAA film rating system (b. 1921)

entities.title: Jack Valenti
entities.description: Jack Joseph Valenti was an American political advisor and lobbyist who served as a Special Assistant to U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson. He was also the longtime president of the Motion Picture Association of America. During his 38-year tenure in the MPAA, he created the MPAA film rating system, and he was generally regarded as one of the most influential pro-copyright lobbyists in the world.

entities.title: Motion Picture Association of America film rating system
entities.description: The Motion Picture Association film rating system is used in the United States and its territories to rate a motion picture's suitability for certain audiences based on its content. The system and the ratings applied to individual motion pictures are the responsibility of the Motion Picture Association (MPA), previously the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) 1945–2019. heading: Deaths
txt: Árpád Orbán, Hungarian footballer (b. 1938)

entities.title: Árpád Orbán
entities.description: Árpád Orbán was a Hungarian Olympic champion football player.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hans Holzer, Austrian-American paranormal investigator and author (b. 1920)

entities.title: Hans Holzer
entities.description: Hans Holzer was an Austrian-American author and parapsychologist. He wrote more than 120 books on supernatural and occult subjects for the popular market as well as several plays, musicals, films, and documentaries, and hosted a television show, Ghost Hunter.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mariam A. Aleem, Egyptian graphic designer and academic (b. 1930)

entities.title: Mariam A. Aleem
entities.description: Mariam A. Aleem was an Egyptian artist and art professor specializing in printed design. She received her Bachelor of Arts from the Faculty of Fine Arts Cairo in 1954 and her Master of Fine Arts in graphic printing 1957 from the University of Southern California. Beginning in 1958, Aleem taught printmaking at the Faculty of Fine Arts in Alexandria. In 1968 she became an assistant professor, headin

heading: Deaths
txt: Urs Felber, Swiss engineer and businessman (b. 1942)

heading: Deaths
txt: Phoebe Snow, American singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1950)

entities.title: Phoebe Snow
entities.description: Phoebe Snow was an American singer-songwriter and guitarist, known for her hit 1975 songs "Poetry Man" and "Harpo's Blues" and her credited guest vocals backing Paul Simon on "Gone at Last". She was described by The New York Times as a "contralto grounded in a bluesy growl and capable of sweeping over four octaves." Snow also sang numerous commercial jingles for many U.S. products during 1980s and

heading: Deaths
txt: Terence Spinks, English boxer and trainer (b. 1938)

entities.title: Terence Spinks
entities.description: Terence "Terry" George Spinks MBE was a boxer from Great Britain, who won the gold medal in the flyweight division at the 1956 Summer Olympics in Melbourne, Australia. In the final he defeated Mircea Dobrescu of Romania on points. He was also British featherweight champion from 1960 to 1961.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jacqueline Brookes, American actress and educator (b. 1930)

entities.title: Jacqueline Brookes
entities.description: Jacqueline Victoire Brookes was an American film, television, and stage actress, best known for her work both off-Broadway and on Broadway.

Hagen and Tom Kibble (GHK). As part of Physical Review Letters' 50th anniversary celebration, the journal recognized this discovery as one of the milestone papers in PRL history. heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Robeson, Jr., American historian and author (b. 1927)

heading: Deaths
txt: DJ Rashad, American electronic musician, producer and DJ  (b. 1979)

heading: Deaths
txt: Jayne Meadows, American actress (b. 1919)

entities.title: Jayne Meadows
entities.description: Jayne Meadows, also known as Jayne Meadows Allen, was an American stage, film and television actress, as well as an author and lecturer. She was nominated for three Emmy Awards during her career and was the elder sister of actress and memoirist Audrey Meadows.

heading: Deaths
txt: Marcel Pronovost, Canadian ice hockey player and coach (b. 1930)

heading: Deaths
txt: Harry Wu, Chinese human rights activist (b. 1937)

entities.title: Harry Wu
entities.description: Harry Wu was a Chinese-American human rights activist. Wu spent 19 years in Chinese labor camps, and he became a resident and citizen of the United States. In 1992, he founded the Laogai Research Foundation.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jonathan Demme, American filmmaker, producer and screenwriter (b. 1944)

entities.title: Jonathan Demme
entities.description: Robert Jonathan Demme was an American film director, producer and screenwriter of film and television who earned widespread acclaim.
